movie_name: America: Imagine a World Without Her

pro_critic_reviews.summary: It's far more invested in elaborate historical reenactments, hypothetical dramatizations and special effects than interviews, research and data.

What he’s doing, it turns out, is lowering the viewer’s standards of proof for a vigorous return to “2016″ territory, a hatchet job on Obama and Obamacare that tries to tie everything to a 1960s “radical” organizer who might have influenced the president.
America is less successful as a debate, since it isn’t one. D’Souza controls the conversation, and thus goes unchallenged when he tries to make real-world points with make-believe scenarios.
Dinesh D'Souza's America: Imagine a World Without Her paints a genuinely troublesome portrait of the country — just not at all in the way he intends.
Here is one more dubious piece of agitprop that will delight the author’s fans and have very little impact on his opponents.

For the most part, however, D’Souza gives the impression of someone obsessed with whitewashing any and all dark chapters in U.S. history books. There are times when his defenses and rationalizations come across as almost laughably facile.

America is like the cinematic equivalent of one of those forwarded e-mails of mostly discredited "facts" that you receive from an uncle and at least those sometimes include family photos or a meat loaf recipe that can be of some value.
Graced with a hilariously definitive title, America is astonishingly facile, a film comprised entirely of straw man arguments.
It's all fist-pumping anti-thought, consisting of baseless revisionist history and idle contrarianism.
Beholden to the same plethora of taboos, half-truths, and outright lies traded en masse by mainstream conservatism for the last seven years.

It would be one thing if D'Souza had an idea, or any idea, he could stick to as a through-line in his project. But America isn't a documentary; it's more like the badly-filmed version of a badly-written, meandering op-ed piece from a paper that lacks fact-checking or proofreading.

user_reviews.text: lol why listen to a bunch of "professionals" who quite literally watch movies for a living when there's a whole internet comment section full of trustworthy anonymous conservatives, many of whom were sheltered from that dreaded pop culture during their childhoods, here to educate you on the finer points of filmmaking and screenwriting and all the other artsy-fartsy things that are actually mostly made by liberals now that I think about it? Can't you sheeple see that each of these "professionals" from disparate parts of the country writing for competing publications are nonetheless part of a great liberal conspiracy to keep the masses ignorant by teaching them how to critically assess the unquestionable truths I just happen to believe in?
I have never been so changed as a person by a cinematic feature such as this movie.

Boring, I actually fell asleep during this movie. It should probably be on TV first, not in theaters. It stuck me as similar to the History Channel Series "America: The Story of Us" that aired a few years ago. Really didn't seem too enjoyable. You know the type: re-en-actors creating scenes from the past with a narrator talking over it. The "history" is questionable.
This is a great movie and finally a movie that highlights America for what it is and not what a certain group wants it to be when all they have to do is move to North Korea.

The trailer for this film describes it as a fictional account of what might have happened if England had won the war and there had never been a USA.  It lies.  The movie is unvarnished, unashamedly dishonest right wing propaganda.  If I wanted that, I could have stayed home and watched Fox news.

This is an awesome documentary about the Lies and Truths of America's founding and historic life changing events.  It took someone from another country (originally India), to point this out.  Dinesh does a brilliant job of it.  He dispels the myths that America's haters promulgate and uses historical facts to accomplish this in an elegant yet profound manner.  DEFINITELY A MUST SEE FILM, FOR EVERY GRADE and HIGH SCHOOL AND COLLEGE STUDENT TO SEE!  Worth 100 times the admission price, to learn the REAL history of America and to stand up for her in life, as every naturalized and born in America, citizens should do!

Everywhere you look .......  Critics bash this movie,  But the ordinary people who go and watch the movie think it is pretty good ...........  LOL  I'll bet more Conservatives enjoyed this movie.  I liked it

This movie is More of a cheaply made poorly acted history reenactment then a smart documentary. This really sucks. Don't waste your moneyy go see something good and not egotistical and dull like this movie.
Propaganda film geared toward the most insane and brainwashed members of society. Directed by a man who committed campaign finance fraud. 14 is a wildly generous score.

I'll give two stars because D'Souza has offered up a far more cogent and coherent documentary argument than most of his ideological stripe ever has before.  Alas, the argument is a failed one, full of holes, inaccuracies, false assumptions, and numerous straw men that get beaten to a pulp while more informed and truthful counterarguments are ignored. It preaches to the choir and will produce few, if any, converts.

HAHAHA. What money can do to preach another piece of lies and garbage. Congrats right wingers! You have another idiot speaking for you. In the 80's I used to give you SOME credit. Now you are just using bots and money to help yer asses. Shame!

America the movie disproves all the propaganda hatred that the left wing lunacy spews everyday in this country. Seeing this movie made me all the more proud to be an American. I am first generation here and my parents left tyranny and poverty for a better life and they achieved it. It would of never been achieved if they stayed in their country. God Bless America...I  love you!

Oh, dear Jesus, what a pathetic piece of **** I tried to sit through the whole thing (on a dare) but just couldn't make it. I'll give this Reagan-era adulterer, campaign-finance crook credit, though -- he spins a hilariously paranoid, tin-foil hat of a fantasy that  is sure to pull in the hoarded gold coins out of the pockets of the A.M. Radio - totally Foxed New crowd. the purpose is to fool the angry, middle- to lower-class whites into believing that  the GOP and Teabaggers care about them instead of the Democrats, when actually all 3 groups -- along with those nutty 13-year-old boys (Libertarians) -- only serve the 0.1%. But hey, keep buying those D'Soused books and movie tickets if it brings you fleeting moments of false comfort.

So I mentioned earlier that I have seen the movie and it was really great. I enjoyed it and appreciated the historical information and reminder that there have been some of the best books written by those who were there from an outside perspective on just how amazing our countries early history was and unique our country is. This movie makes you really feel proud of our country and recognize you can still today share the rest of what has been omitted in NEW history books to let those around us know America is amazing. It builds this perspective while allowing those who actually HATE America to say what they feel about it in their own words. It is a debate per se with their thoughts and not just a single example they make but many. Followed by an answer to each.

Take the politics out of  "America" and it remains historically accurate, thought-provoking, beautifully photographed and verifiably challenging to those with arthritis of the frontal lobe. Intellectual honesty requires viewing this film as what it is--a documentary--not a homage. Those expecting anything else will be disappointed. "America" is disturbing to those stuck in either corner of the political extreme. Those who see it armed with few facts and strong opinions will be disappointed. Those who see it with open minds and hearts will leave uplifted.
America gives the Conservative view to history that schools have taken out of history books. A great movie to take your kids to see so they learn about our wonderful country!

I loved the film, it was informative and there were somethings that I didn't know about. D'Souza is factual, he doesn't hide the facts that America did make mistakes, but when you compare this country to the rest of the world, we have worked hard to fix any mistakes that we have made.  I was entertained throughout the whole movie, and  left feeling really good about being a citizen of this country and this country in general.  Everyone is entitled to their opinion, after all that is what makes America great.  What isn't so much fun anymore about the people commenting is that they attack the commentator.  I think we are above that.
Hooah! Molon Labe and Alex Jones!

Highly recommend this movie - refreshing and enlightening - another outstanding documentary by Dinesh D'Souza. Pay no attention to the lame loser left movie critics - this movie is well worth the time & cost.

Yes, America is great. But America has also committed some terrible mistakes in the past and will likely commit some terrible mistakes in the future. Not acknowledging the entirety of America's past, in addition to not admitting that the current political and economic structure is flawed (and has been for decades, not just under President Obama) and in desperate need of reform is where the film falls to pieces, frankly. And to place the blame of all of the current woes on a President who has been blocked by the other party on practically every attempt at legislation is foolish at worst and nonsensical at best. D'Souza is very good at building an argument for his beliefs, but he is nothing more than a demagogue. If you are a conservative, it will affirm your beliefs. But it does nothing to actually foster critical thinking and analysis.

Of course the critics hate this movie.  They are part of the unbelievably biased liberal media that wants to run this country.  Anything that doesn't mindlessly echo the apologetic attitude coming from the white house is ripped apart and deemed to have no value.  I hope they enjoy attending their multiple thousand dollar fundraisers for Obama while they rant and cry about all the dark chapters and untold horrors committed by the country that made their enormous successes possible.

Those who disagree with the filmmaker, Dinesh D'Souza, will appreciate the voices of criticism included, even highlighted, in the film.  Those more friendly to his message, will be very emotionally moved, and intellectually inspired.
You must see this movie!
Definitely worth seeing if you like to see both sides of the arguments. I think the movie brings up some good points.

on't listed to the Obama drones in here this is a fun to watch and meaningful movie that heavily challenges the commy worldview of the fascists on the left.   Hilarious how Obamas IRS attacked Dinesh and any dissent is met with violent attacks. So much for listening to the will of the majority in the USA.  Democrats are communists and are a minority in this country.  Democrats cause the very crony problems they claim to fight and want to silence all opposition.  Lowering government spending makes the poor move to the middle class.   Communism has never worked.  See the movie its awesome!

Excellent film production and documentary. So much of what was shared in this film has been taken out of history books and the classrooms by the far left liberals who don't want you to know the truth about our great country.  Dinesh D'Souza and Gerald Molen are two quality filmmakers that once again highlight the exceptional-ism of America, and a world without her. It's interesting that more and more foreign born migrants that come here appreciate and love the greatness of this country more than our own natural born citizens.  What does that tell you about the direction of this country? More dependence on big government, less dependence on self.
*CRITICS* .. open your eyes and take a step down from your liberally-biased media talking points !

You can pretty much ignore anything the "critics" say on this movie or any other movie made by conservatives and ordinary Americans like you and me. That being said, this movie points out things we've known all along about what this administration is trying to do. Don't be fooled into what the leftist say about this movie, go see and educate yourself about the America that's backsliding and how YOU can stop it. knowledge is power.
This is an engaging and well crafted political documentary by a leading conservative intellectual. It's refreshing to see the criticisms of the US examined and answered.

Oh goodie! All the extreme left, America-hating,Obama-worshiping, tingle-up-my-leg, historically illiterate, East Coast elitist, limousine liberal, Mercedes Marxist d-bags gave this movie their screaming, eye-rolling, breath-holding, bed-wetting anathemas! That explains why I and most of the other people who actually saw the movie applauded at the end. You must not miss this movie!

As far as movie making goes this film is pretty well put together. This is not a big budget affair so my expectations were not sky high. I was however pleasantly surprised by the overall presentation. I agree with many of the professional critics that seem a little confused as to why he begins the film with the premise of General Washington being killed by a sniper and I expected a documentary about the world without America. Of course the film moves away form that premise and towards a general discussion of the "indictments against America" and a soft rebuttal to them. So that abrupt change in direction was a bit awkward. That aside, this was a very fair representation of two schools of thought about America and her place in the world. Clearly D'Souza has conservative leaning personal beliefs and this film makes no effort to hide that. it can and should be noted that, neither did Michael Moore with any of his popular documentary features. Unlike Mr. Moore, D'Souza is mostly respectful towards those with opposing viewpoints. The movie is not an all out assault on the left but rather an gentle nudge towards the idea that America is not nearly as bad as some on the left insist. The film will touch on sensitive subject matter, but I believe handles it in a professional and respectful way. Mr D'Souza opens the narrative with the calm statement that  "I Love America". Make no mistake that he shows a bit of patriotic pride towards the end of the film. Whether you are a dyed in the wool lefty or a hard line righty or somewhere in between... This is a good movie to watch and think about. Put aside you angry politics and soak in the idea that America has been both a shining beacon on the hill and the occasional oppressor. But in the end, America has worked to right her wrongs and help others achieve the better opportunity we have enjoyed. Perhaps we are not as bad as some say we are.

It is very well produced and enjoyable as long as you walk in knowing it is in a documentary format. It is both brave and tragic; brave of D’Souza to shine a light on so much truth that is now considered politically incorrect, yet tragic that so few news or educational sources report on these truths. Also whether or not it was intentional, Metacritic has done us all a great favor in segregating critics from the rest of us. Especially for a politically charged film like this, the Metacritic format exposes mainstream media so-called “critics” for what their true liberal bias shows they are.

I loved this movie.  Well thought out.  The countries critics arguments are laid out by the critics themselves and then dismantled by facts one by one.  Historical accounts woven in beautifully.  I learned some history that surprised me.  This should be shown in every classroom in America.

The movie was ery thought provoking and insightful.  Every American should see this film.  Would highly recommend the movie, presents the true history of the US and where our apathy could be leading our society!

Another worthwhile documentary from D'Souza and Molen.  This time around we are asked to contemplate the world without the USA.  Inspiring and compelling, it's more even handed than "Obama's America,"  with higher production values.  Bottom line, it's way more fun to watch than D'Souza's last film.  The fact that it has an A+ Cinemascore from viewers and a 15 from Critic Reviews on Metacritic says all you need to know.  Watch and enjoy!
Just saw the film last night and was captivated!  Much better than anything by Moore.  The only reason I can think the critics don't like is the tone of the message, which is very pro-United States.
Snore! I really wish I could get back the 20 minutes I wasted before walking out of this gab fest from Dinesh D'Souza, Inc. There is nothing here that's not in his bland, fake-factoid filled books.

Went to see this after reading a couple of unbelievably negative reviews.  So very glad I did. While one could nit-pick at a lack of big name actors and re-enactments that are a little shy of 100 million blockbusters, that would only emphasize that you've missed the point of this documentary. The message, story, and heart of this movie were spot on.  A fantastic execution of both education and uplifting inspiration.  Seems like we've been promised hope for a long time now... finally, someone delivered.

My Husband and I took 22 friends and family members to see this movie on the 4th of July. The collective quality of this movie was indeed a surprise and I’m so glad we saw it. This movie will elicit humor, emotion, pride and history within the historical context. This is one of those movies that won’t hit you fully until the next day. My Husband purchased the book and told me how great it was. I will be reading the book this week and want to see the movie again this weekend. As being from a large Hispanic family where our family Patriarch and Matriarch immigrated lawfully settling the family in Kansas City in the 50’s, I would recommend this movie my fellow Hispanic citizens and to all Americans including children 9 years or older. A breath of fresh air from the movie industry and the producers of this film took extraordinary steps to make this not a movie but an event. Thank you so much……
This is an excellent film... brave and honest. Beautifully filmed, D'Souza shows us our Country's flaws and its greatness.

Ignore the critics.  Ignore anyone who tells you this is not a good documentary.  It's not a "movie", folks.  It's there to inform, not entertain - at least not entirely.  But how many documentaries (at least those without penguins or other cute animals in them) do you go to where the audience rises and applauds at the end?  I knew of many of the things described in this film, but was pleasantly surprised to learn others!  I will, for instance, remember to memorialize Mme. C.J. Walker, the first black woman millionaire, next February during Black History Month!  I will not do the same for the black slave holders.  America is exceptional, don't let anyone tell you different.  Find out why by going to this brilliant new film.

D'Souza makes an effective and fair defense of America - what makes her special - and provides the proper moral and historical context for various injustices in our history.  I find it ironic that critics are accusing D'Souza of making straw-man arguments and withholding key facts or arguments in the discussion of slavery, capitalism, etc. D'Souza does nothing of the sort.  He very fairly states the general accusations of those on the left who accuse the US of illegitimacy because of slavery, capitalism, imperialism, etc. He pokes holes in arguments made by well-known professors and political commentators on the left (Noam Chomsky, Howard Zinn, etc.) and fills in critical details intentionally left out to support an "America is evil and needs to be re-made" conclusion. This is definitely NOT an instance where D'Souza parades up a bunch of light-weights making specious arguments. I find it laughable, but sadly not surprising, that several very left-leaning critics gave America a "0" out of 100.  I note that these same critics thought some hatchet-job documentary on the Koch brothers (I know - even the mere mention of their names should cause all acceptably left-leaning citizens to convulse in anger) was "passionate" but "fair" and not "vituperative."  They even gave Transformers close to a score of 40.  It's obvious that these critics measure the worth of a documentary not on its truth or accessibility but on its political message.  Ultimately, it appears a "good" documentary starts with a conclusion they support, e.g. "corporations and Christians are bad and big-government atheist liberals are good", and then selectively back-fit data to support this conclusion.  Oh, and if you can sufficiently rabble-rouse and inspire people to rise up against "the man", that makes the documentary even better.  Since America is a fair and compelling argument in defense of the "idea" of America (quoting Bono from US in the movie) - that of liberty, free enterprise, and entrepreneurship - this does not sit well with several of the critics who give the movie a score of 0.  This is dishonest but sadly expected.  Go see this movie and bring your kids.  You'll be glad you did.

If you combine the Movie America with the ratings on this site it helps to explain the real political divide in this country.  The leftist so called elitist who run most of the main stream media cannot stand any view point that goes against them so they slam it without merit often.  The movie overall was very interesting and well done and I encourage everyone regardless of political party affiliation to watch it with an open mind.  Forget what the so called critics think and listen to the people.

Unfortunately, I fully expect that the majority of critics out there (because the majority are out spoken liberals) will be viciously harsh and overly critical whether overtly or subtly about this movie. I can see all the reviews like this one saying things like its racist, xenophobic, jingoistic, idiotic, or just plain hateful. So if someone is interested in watching I just hope they know the ideology of most of the media's critics out there.

Not what I expected. I heard the terrible reviews and poor performance at the box office. I arrived at a 505 showing on a Sunday st 520. The movie was just about to start. The theater waa about 75% full. Everyone clapped at the end. Going to check into who sang the national anthem at the end. Great documentary and pro America. I will go see again.

This movie is obviously not going to sit very well with people on the left side of the political aisle. However, this movie presents some very good points and as a documentary it is very well executed. To not make this long, I came out of the movie theater proud to be an American and i would recommend it to anyone (conservative, liberal or in-between) planning to vote on the upcoming elections.

The wide disparity between professional and public ratings of 'America' suggests that newspaper critics have goose-stepped sharply to the left in order to keep their jobs with their increasingly left-tilting employers. Bottom line, you'll hate 'America' if you're one of the bozos who think Obama is doing a great job. However, if you side with most Americans, who in a recent poll  said they regarded Obama as the worst president of the last century (a charitable assessment, by the way, since Obama is easily the worst presdient U.S. history), then you'll hate this film. Putting aside their churish and untoward comments, some of which are flat-out wrong, the film is not great, but it's not bad either. If it fails to persuade, it is only because the pro-Obama arguments it poses are too numerous and well-drawn to rebut in a two-hour film.

The "professional" reviewers show their true colors. Just as the major media markets are aligned with Obama as to be part of his public relations team. They are not fair and balanced in any way whatsoever. If they were, then every Michael Moore movie that was made, and were made by completely arranging the events of the movie so as to be rigged, would have been rated with the same vitriol that these professional snots have rated this movie.

"And in other shocking news, leftist movie critics give 'America' horrible reviews."  Let's be honest for a minute: This movie is good, but not awesome. But the great thing about this film is it's truth and a lack of lies, crudeness and vulgarity, all of which, apparently, must be present for modern movie critics to hold a film in high regard. Take yourself and your family to see a film that puts our country's and its sins (...and its great accomplishments) in perspective. America (the country) is exceptional, not because we're "better" than other people, rather we're exceptional because have largely been an exception to the typical tyranny that most people in history have had to live under. Critics apparently cannot comprehend this notion, so go see this decent film and pray that we can remain a nation of freedom (a true exception in the world).

Great movie!  With all the left wing hatred and intolerance doctrine against America and the freedoms we all take for granted, the movie was brave and thought provoking.  One can only hope, the decisions being made politically today won't cause an uprising in this country.

Michael Moore may not be able to sleep because Dinesh is his worst nightmare. Its a horror film for liberals! Liberals don't argue on truth or facts but on which this film will be hard for them to stand corrected by their errors about history. But it doesn't matter because once somebody is wrong they will find a new excuse and loophole to protest their cause to be right, just as the kid who says I know it was wrong to hit him but he started it first. Two wrongs don't make a right.

Great and truthful movie.  Must see and be honest to yourself and your country.  America has borders (or used to have) to keep people out of it.  Other countries, Cuba, Russia, all communist/socialist countries, build borders to keep people (citizens) in.

The worst documentary I've ever seen, this film is a nasty, boring, idiotic, and unfocused propaganda film, with no idea of what it really wants to be! The film is one big mess, with no true, exact focus. I don't even know if it is anti or pro American!
Great Documentary,  well worth watching.  Well  written and thought out. Doesn't lag like at all, moves quickly and is uplifting. It will leave you feeling good.
Another example of critics who hate America.
